member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimatableProperty`1
member.summary: Represents a property that can be animated. (Default implementation.)
member.typeparam: The type of the property.

remarks.para: An represents a standalone value, which can be animated by the animation system. (Use if you want to animate an existing field or property instead of creating a standalone value.)
provides a default implementation of the interface which is required by the animation system. It internally stores two values: a base value and an animation value.

Base Value: The base value is the value of the property that is valid when no animations are active. The animation system reads the base value but does not change it. The base value is used by certain types of animations: For example, additive animations will add the result of the animations to the base value value. Another example are "From-To-Animations": If only the "To" value is defined then the animation will animate from the base value of the property to the "To" value defined in the animation.

Animation Value: The animation value of the property is determined by the animations that are controlling the property. The properties and are set by the animations system and should be treated as read-only. is when an animation is active; indicates that no animations are active. In this case the base value is the effective value of the property.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimatableProperty`1.Value
member.summary: Gets or sets the value of the property.
member.value: The value of the property.
member.remarks: Writing changes the base value of the property. Reading returns the effective value of the property. (If the property is animated, then the animation value is effective value. If no animations are active, then the base value is the effective value.)

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.DelegateAnimatableProperty`1
member.summary: Wraps an existing field or property and makes it animatable.
member.typeparam: The type of the property.

remarks.para: The animation system can only animate objects of type . Normal CLR field or properties do not implement this interface and can therefore not be animated directly. The wraps an existing field or property and makes it accessible for the animation system.
The requires two callbacks: One that reads the value (see ) and one that writes the value (). The callbacks can read/write any existing field or property.
This type of does not have a , which means that it does not support additive animations or certain types of from/to/by-animations. Use instead of if this functionality is required.

Note: The animation system does not keep animatable properties alive. It automatically removes animations if the is no longer referenced by another object. This means, the created needs to be kept alive as long as the property should be animated.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationController
member.summary: Provides interactive control over an animation.

remarks.para:
Animation controllers provide interactive control over animations. They are created when a new animation is started using one of the StartAnimation-methods of the . Animation controllers can also be created explicitly by calling one of the CreateController-methods. Using the animation controller the user can:
Start the animation by calling , if the animation is not already running.
Pause the animation by calling . (The animation will hold its current animation value, but won't advance.)
Continue a previously paused animation by calling .
Stop an animation by calling .
Query the state of the animation using the property .
Query the current time of the animation by reading the property .
Jump to a certain point in time by setting the property .
Etc.

Animation State and Timing: The property returns the current state of the animation. The animation can be , , or . But the state does not indicate whether the animation timing is active. The property indicates whether the animation timing is active or paused.
Memory Management: The following information is relevant for users who want to reduce garbage collector (GC) overhead, in particular on the Xbox 360.
The type is a value type (struct). It is a lightweight handle that stores a reference to the and the .

Objects of type are automatically created when a new animation controller is created. The animation instances maintain the runtime-state of the animations. Animation instances can be recycled when they are no longer used. They can then be reused by the animation system for future animations.

It is recommended to recycle animation instances in order to reduce the number of memory allocations at runtime. Animation instances can be recycled explicitly by calling . Or, they can be recycled automatically by calling or setting the property to . If is set, then the animation system will automatically recycle the animation instances once the animation has stopped. The property is by default.
The method can be called at any time, regardless of whether is set. The property can also be changed at any time - it will only take effect when the animation stops.
Once the animation instance has been recycled the struct becomes invalid. The property indicates whether the animation instance is still alive or has already been recycled.

It is recommended to recycle animation instances in order to reduce the number of memory allocations at runtime. Animation instances can be recycled explicitly by calling . Note that calling the methods , , or setting the property has no effect if the animation controller is invalid.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationController.Start

overloads.summary: Starts the animation.

member.summary: Starts the animation immediately.

remarks.para: The animation will be started immediately using . Call if another type of transition (for example, a fade-in) should be used.

Important: When animations are started or stopped the animations do not take effect immediately. That means the new animation values are not immediately applied to the properties that are being animated. The animations are evaluated when the animation system is updated (see ) and new animation values are written when is called.
The method can be called to immediately evaluate and apply the animation. But in most cases it is not necessary to call this method explicitly.

member.exception: Cannot start animation. The animation instance associated with the current animation controller is already running or has already been recycled and the animation controller is no longer valid.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationController.UpdateAndApply
member.summary: Immediately evaluates the animation and applies the new animation values.

remarks.para: When an animation is started or stopped, the values of the animated properties do not change immediately. The new animation values will be computed and set when the animation system is updated. See and .

But in certain cases when an animation is started or stopped the animated properties should be updated immediately. In these case the method needs to be called after the animation is started or stopped. This method immediately evaluates the animation and applies the new animation values to the properties that are being animated.
The method can also be called if an animation is modified (e.g. key frames are added or removed) and the changes should take effect immediately.
In most cases it is not necessary to call this method because the animation service updates and applies animations automatically.
Note that does not advance the time of the animation. The animation is evaluated at the current time.

member.exception: Cannot update and apply animation. The animation instance associated with the current animation controller is already running or has already been recycled and the animation controller is no longer valid.

member.returns: The compressed animation. Or if the animation does contain any key frames.

remarks.para: This method takes an and removes not needed scale, rotation or translation channels. It further removes key frames that can be interpolated from the neighbor key frames. This a lossy compression and the threshold parameters define the allowed errors. If the thresholds are 0 or negative, this compression is lossless. If the thresholds are greater than 0 (recommended), the compression is lossy. The best way to determine optimal thresholds is to compare the compressed animation with the uncompressed animation visually.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationInstance
member.summary: Represents an instance of an animation timeline.

remarks.para: Animation instances are used to play back animations. They maintain the runtime-state of an animation.

Animation instances are automatically created and managed by the animation system when a new animation is started using one of the StartAnimation-methods or when an animation controller is created using one of the CreateController-methods (see ).

Animation Value: An animation usually produces a value as the output. The base class manages the timeline of the animation. The derived class manages the animation value. The animation system automatically applies the output values to the properties that are being animated (see ).

Animation State and Timing: The property returns the current state of the animation. The animation can be , , or . But the state does not indicate whether the animation timing is active. The property indicates whether the animation timing is active or paused.
Active animations are managed by the . The animation system automatically advances and updates the animations.

The current state of an animation is computed once per frame (in ) and cached until the next frame. The animation instance does not monitor the animation for changes. I.e. when the animation is modified the animation instance needs to be notified by calling . Otherwise, it can return an invalid state in the current frame. For example, an animation instance plays a certain . During playback the user changes the of the animation. Now, when the user reads in the same frame the instance might return the wrong value. The user needs to call to get the correct, up-to-date value. (It is not necessary to call if the animations are updated using . automatically computes the new values.)

Animation Tree: Animation instances can have children. For example, when a is started it creates a root instance that has several children - one animation instance per animation in the timeline group. A timeline group might contain other timeline groups. The animation instances are organized in a tree structure.
Only the root instance of a tree can be controlled interactively (using an ).

Speed Ratio: The playback speed of the animation tree can be controlled by changing the property . The speed ratio defines the rate at which time progresses. The default value is 1. A value of, for example, 2 means that the animation runs twice as fast. A value of 0.5 causes the animation to run in slow-motion at half speed.
Note that the only the speed ratio of the root instance in the animation tree can be controlled. (Changing the speed ratio of other nodes in the animation tree has no effect.)

Animation Weights: Each animation instance has a weight (see ) that defines the intensity of the animation. It is a factor that is applied to the animation output. The animation weight is in particular relevant when multiple animations should be combined. Each animation combines its output with the output of the previous stage in the animation composition chain. (If the animation is the first animation of a composition chain it combines its value with the base value of the property that is being animated.)

The default value is 1, which means that 100% of the animation is returned overriding any previous stage in an animation composition chain. A value of 0.75 means that result is weighted combination of the previous stage (25%) and the output of the current animation (75%). A value of 0 basically disables the output of the current stage.

Changing the animation weight of an instance affects the entire subtree: The current animation instance and all children. The effective animation weight is the product of all weights from the root instance to the current animation instance.

Secondary Animations: An animation instance itself is an , which means that it has properties which can be animated. The properties that can be animated are and . Secondary animation can be used, for example, to fade-in an animation by letting the animation weight go from 0 to 1 over time.

remarks.para: The animation weight defines the intensity of the animation. It is a factor that is applied to the animation output. The animation weight is in particular relevant when multiple animations should be combined. Each animation combines its output with the output of the previous stage in the animation composition chain. (If the animation is the first animation of a composition chain it combines its value with the base value of the property that is being animated.)

The default value is 1 which means that 100% of the animation is returned, overriding any previous stage in a animation composition chain. A value of 0.75 means that result is weighted combination of the previous stage (25%) and the output of the current animation (75%). A value of 0 basically disables the output of the current animation.

Changing the animation weight of an instance affects the entire subtree: the current animation instance and all children. The effective animation weight is the product of all weights from the root node to the current animation instance.

member.name: E:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationInstance.Completed
member.summary: Occurs when the animation has completed playing. Use with caution - see remarks.

remarks.para: A root instance has completed playing when the root timeline has reached the end of its duration (including any repeats). A child instance is considered to have finished playing when the root instance has finished playing.

Important: The completion event does not trigger when animation is explicitly stopped or removed before it has reached the end of its duration. (But the completion event is triggered when the user sets the to a value past the end of the duration.)

The completion event is not raised immediately when the state of the animation changes. Instead, the records all animations that have finished playing in and explicitly raises the completion events in .

Use with Caution: The animation system uses weak references to ensure that animations do not accidentally keep the animated objects and properties alive. Animations are automatically removed if the animated objects are removed (i.e. garbage collected). But the event stores the event handlers using a strong reference. If an event handler keeps the animation objects or properties alive, then the animation system will not be able to automatically remove the animation and the referenced resources. To ensure that all resources are properly freed, make sure that one of the following conditions is true:
The completion event handlers do not keep the target object or properties that are being animated alive.
The completion event handlers are removed explicitly if they are no longer required.
The animation is stopped explicitly when it is no longer needed, e.g. by calling ).
The animation is stopped implicitly, e.g. by starting a new animation which replaces it.
The animation has a limited duration and stops automatically. (The needs to be set to .)

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationInstance`1.GetValue(`0@,`0@,`0@)
member.summary: Gets the current animation value.
member.param: In: The source value that should be used by the animation if the animation does not have its own source value.
In: The target value that should be used by the animation if the animation does not have its own target value.
Out: The value of the animation at the current time. (The animation returns if the animation is currently or .)

remarks.para: Note that the parameters need to be passed by reference. and are input parameters. The resulting animation value is stored in .

The values of the and the parameters depend on where the animation is used. If the animation is used to animate an , then the values depend on the position of the animation in the composition chain:
If the animation has replaced another animation using : is the last output value of the animation which was replaced and is the base value of the animated property.
If the animation is the first in an animation composition chain: and are the base value of the animated property.
If the animation is not the first in an animation composition chain: is the output of the previous stage in the composition chain and is the base value of the animated property.

If the animation is not used to animate an , the values need to be set by the user depending on the context where the animation is used. (In most cases it is safe to ignore the parameters and just pass default values.)

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationManager
member.summary: Represents the animations system which can be used to play back animations.

remarks.para: This class implements the . See documentation of .

This class has two important methods: must be called once per frame, and it updates all managed animations. The new animation values are internally cached but not applied until is called. can usually be called parallel to other game services (graphics, physics, AI, etc.). should be called when it is safe to write the animation results to the animated objects and properties.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationManager.EnableMultithreading
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether multithreading is enabled.
member.value: if multithreading is enabled; otherwise, . The default value is if the current system has more than one CPU cores.

remarks.para: When multithreading is enabled the animation system will distribute the workload across multiple processors (CPU cores) to improve the performance.

Multithreading adds an additional overhead, therefore it should only be enabled if the current system has more than one CPU core and if the other cores are not fully utilized by the application. Multithreading should be disabled if the system has only one CPU core or if all other CPU cores are busy. In some cases it might be necessary to run a benchmark of the application and compare the performance with and without multithreading to decide whether multithreading should be enabled or not.

The animation system internally uses the class for parallelization. is a static class that defines how many worker threads are created, how the workload is distributed among the worker threads and more. (See to find out more on how to configure parallelization.)

member.summary: Evaluates the animation function at the specified animation time.
member.param: In: The source value that should be used by the animation if the animation does not have its own source value.
In: The target value that should be used by the animation if the animation does not have its own target value.
Out: The value of the animation at the given time.

remarks.para: The method implements the animation function. It is called automatically by to compute the current animation value.
Note that the parameters are passed by reference. and are input parameters. The resulting animation value is stored in .

The values of the and the parameter depends on where the animation is used. If the animation is used to animate an then the values depend on the position of the animation in the composition chain:
If the animation has replaced another animation using : is the last output value of the animation which was replaced and is the base value of the animated property.
If the animation is the first in an animation composition chain: and are the base value of the animated property.
If the animation is not the first in an animation composition chain: is the output of the previous stage in the composition chain and is the base value of the animated property.

Notes to Inheritors: The sole purpose of this method is to evaluate the animation function at the given time. All other tasks (handling of additive animations, animation blending) are automatically handled by the base class.
The parameter contains the local time of the animation. (Any parameters such as , , , or have already been applied.)

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationState
member.summary: Defines the state of an animation.

remarks.para: Animations are positioned on a timeline. The current state of an animation depends on the current time on the timeline. The method can be used to query the current state for a given time value.
indicates that the animation is active and produces animation values.

The animation state is when the timeline is active, but the start of the animation has been delayed. The types and can be used to delay the start of an animation. The animation state is as long as the current time is less than the . The animation does not produce an output in this state.
When the time value reaches the end of the duration the state becomes either when the is set to or when the fill behavior is set to .

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationState.Stopped

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationState.Playing
member.summary: The animation is active and produces an animation value.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationState.Filling
member.summary: The duration of the animation is exceeded and the animation returns the last animation value.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationClip`1
member.summary: Plays back a clip of another animation.
member.typeparam: The type of the animation value.

remarks.para:
The has the following purposes:
Select animation clip: The properties and can be used to select an interval from another animation (see property ). The properties are optional: and are by default, which means that the entire animation is selected. It is also possible to set only or - in this case only one side of the original animation will be clipped.
The property defines a time offset which is applied when the animation clip is played back. If the selected clip is, for example, 10 seconds long and is 5 seconds, then the playback of the clip will start in the middle.
Arrange animation clip on timeline: The properties , , can be used to position the selected animation clip along the timeline: The start of the animation clip can be postponed using the property . The duration of the animation can be overridden using the property . Note that, when the duration exceeds the actual length of the clip than the clip is automatically repeated using a certain loop behavior (see below). The defines the rate at which the animation clip is played back.

Loop Behavior: The property defines the length of the playback. If the duration is not set (default value is ), the animation clip plays exactly once (clip length = - ). If the users sets a duration greater than the actual length of the clip, the clip is repeated using a certain loop behavior.

The property defines the behavior past the end of the animation clip. The default loop behavior is which means that the last value of the animation clip is returned for the rest of the duration. The loop behavior causes the animation clip to be repeated from the start. The loop behavior is similar to except that it also applies an offset to the animation values in each new iteration. The loop behavior (also known as 'auto-reverse' or 'ping-pong') automatically repeats the animation clip in reverse order, so that the animation clip is played back and forth for the defined duration.

member.value: The original animation from which a clip is played back.

member.remarks: and define the interval of the original animation that should be played.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationClip`1.ClipOffset
member.summary: Gets the time offset that is applied to the selected animation clip.
member.value: A time offset that is applied to the animation clip. The default value is 0.

remarks.para: The property defines a time offset which is applied when the animation clip is played back. If the selected clip is, for example, 10 seconds long and is 5 seconds, then the playback of the clip will start in the middle.
By default, the animation clip is played forward from to . In this case the is added to the .
When is set, the animation clip is played backward from to . In this case the is subtracted from .

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationClip`1.IsClipReversed
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to play the clip in reverse.
member.value: if the clip is played in reverse; otherwise, . The default value is .

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationClip`1.Delay
member.summary: Gets or sets the time at which the animation clip begins.
member.value: The time at which the animation should begin. The default value is 0.

remarks.para: This property can be used to delay the start of an animation. The delay time marks the time on the timeline when the animation clip starts. The does not affect the delay. For example, an animation clip with a delay of 3 seconds, a duration of 10 seconds and a speed ratio of 2 will start after 3 seconds and run for 5 seconds with double speed.
Note: The delay time can also be negative. For example, an animation with a delay time of -2.5 seconds and a duration of 5 seconds will start right in the middle of the animation clip.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationClip`1.Duration
member.summary: Gets or sets the duration for which the animation clip is played.
member.value: The duration for which the animation clip is played. The default value is , which indicates that the animation clip should be played once from to .

remarks.para: The properties and define the duration of the animation clip. If the properties are not set then the original animation is played in its entirety. The property can be set to override the duration of the animation clip. If is greater than the length of the animation clip, the clip will be repeated using the defined loop behavior (see ).

The effective duration depends on the : For example, an animation clip with a delay of 3 seconds, a duration of 10 seconds and a speed ratio of 2 will start after 3 seconds and run for 5 seconds with double speed.

The default value is , which indicates that the duration is 'automatic' or 'unknown'. In this case the animation clip plays exactly once. A duration of can be set to repeat the animation clip forever.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationClip`1.Speed
member.summary: Gets or sets the speed ratio at which the animation clip is played.
member.value: The rate at which time progresses for the animation clip. The value must be a finite number greater than or equal to 0. The default value is 1.
member.exception: is negative or not a finite value.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationClip`1.LoopBehavior
member.summary: Gets or sets the behavior of the animation past the end of the animation clip.
member.value: The behavior of the animation past the end of the animation clip. The default value is .

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationCurve`4
member.summary: Animates a value using an animation curve. (Base implementation.)
member.typeparam: The type of the animation value.
The type of the curve points, such as , , etc.
The type of the curve key. (A type derived from .)
The type of the curve. (A type derived from .)

remarks.para: The animation curve (see property ) contains several curve keys (also known as 'key frames') that define the change of the value. The curve parameter is the animation time. A curve key defines the current value at a certain point in time. It also defines the type of interpolation that is used for the segment between the current and the next curve key. All relevant types of spline-based interpolations can be used for the curve segments.

Duration: An animation curve, by default, runs from the start (curve parameter = 0) until the last curve key is reached. The parameter of the last curve key determines the natural duration of the animation. The optional properties and can be used to explicitly define which part of the animation curve should be played.

Loop Behavior: When the is less than the parameter of the first curve key or is greater than the parameter of the last curve key then the curve is automatically repeated using a certain loop behavior. The loop behavior can be defined using the properties and of the .
Important: The animation curve requires that the curve keys are sorted ascending by their parameter (time value). The method can be called to sort all curve keys.

The type of the path key. (A type derived from .)

remarks.para: A path animation moves a point in space along a predefined path (see property ). The animation path is a spline-based curve consisting of several path keys (also known as 'key frames'). A path key defines a point in space. The parameter of a path key is the animation time - the time at which the point on the path is reached. A path key also defines the type of interpolation that is used for the segment between the current and the next path key. All relevant types of spline-based interpolations can be used for the path segments.

Duration: A path animation, by default, runs from the start (parameter = 0) until the last path key is reached. The parameter of the last path key determines the natural duration of the animation. The optional properties and can be used to explicitly define which part of the path should be played.

Loop Behavior: When the is less than the parameter of the first path key or is greater than the parameter of the last path key then the path is automatically repeated using a certain loop behavior. The loop behavior can be defined using the properties and of the .
Important: The path animation requires that the path keys are sorted ascending by their parameter (time value). The method can be called to sort all path keys.

member.summary: Animates a value from/to/by a certain value. (Only available in the XNA-compatible build.)

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.FromToByAnimation`1
member.summary: Animates a value from/to/by a certain value. (Base implementation.)
member.typeparam: The type of the animation value.

remarks.para:
This type of animation changes a value from, to, or by a certain value depending on the properties set:
Properties Specified Resulting Behavior
From and To
The animation interpolates between the value specified by and the value specified by .
From and By
The animation interpolates between the value specified by and the sum of the values specified by and .
From
The animation interpolates between the value specified by and the default source value (see parameters of ).
When an is animated this means that the value is animated towards the output of the previous animation. If there is no previous animation, then the value is animated towards the base value of the property.
To
The animation interpolates from the default source value (see parameters of ) to the value specified by .
When an is animated this means that the output of the previous animation is animated towards the value. If there is no previous animation, then the base value of the property is animated towards the value.
By
The animation interpolates from the default source value (see parameters of ) to the sum of this value plus the value specified by .
When an is animated this means that the output of the previous animation is animated towards the sum of the this value plus the value. If there is no previous animation, then the base value of the property is animated towards the sum of the base value plus the value.
No properties set
The animation interpolates between the default source value to the default target value (see parameters of ).
When an is animated this means that the previous animation's output value is animated towards the base value of the property.
If both and are specified, the value will be ignored.
The property specifies the period of time over which the interpolation takes place.
By default, the animation interpolates linearly between the specified values. An easing function (see property ) can be applied to control the pace of the transition.

The property can be set to add the output of the animation to the property that is being animated. Note that the animation needs to be fully defined to be additive. A from/to/by animation is fully defined if either and or and are set. The result is undefined if the animation is only partially defined (either the start or the final value is missing)!

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.IAnimation
member.summary: Defines the change of a value over time.

remarks.para: An animation in the traditional sense is the rapid display of images to create the illusion of movement. Here, in DigitalRune Animation, the term animation is used in a more general way: An animation determines the change of value over time.

Animations can be applied to all kinds of properties in an application. In a user-interface properties such as size, position, rotation, color, opacity, etc. can be animated to create interesting visual effects. In virtual worlds more complex animations can be used to control the motions of objects or virtual characters.

An animation defines the transition of a value over time. It is basically a function x = f(t) where the parameter t is called the animation time and the result x is the animation value. The method can be used to evaluate the animation value.

Target Object and Property: An animation can be applied to a property of a given object. The animation system allows to apply an animation to an object or a group of objects without explicitly specifying the property that should be animated. In this case the animation system automatically matches the target object and properties using the properties and . and are optional strings that can be set to identify the target.

For example, a can be used to define a complex set of animations. Each animation is assigned to an object/property by setting and . At runtime, when the is started the animation system will automatically apply the animations to the matching objects.

The animation system first checks whether the property is set and matches the name of any of the given objects. The animation system assumes that all objects have a unique name. Therefore, as soon as one match is found the animation system ignores all remaining objects/properties. If a match is found, it checks whether the object has a matching animatable property. If the property is not set (the value is or an empty string), the animation system checks all objects for a matching property.

The animation system checks whether an animatable property matches the property and whether the type of the property is compatible with the animation. An animation is applied to the first matching property. If there are multiple potential matches the animation is only applied to the first match.

Note that timelines can be nested. In this case the parent's or property overrides the values set by child animations. For example, if the property is set in a the value overrides the properties of all child animations/timelines.

Additive Animations: Animations can be additive, meaning that the animation value is added to the target property. If there are multiple animation in an composition chain, the animation value will be added to the output of the previous stage. If the animation is the first animation in a composition chain, the animation value is added to the base value of the property that is being animated.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Animation.IAnimation`1.GetValue(System.TimeSpan,`0@,`0@,`0@)
member.summary: Gets the value of the animation at the specified time.
member.param: The time value on the timeline.
In: The source value that should be used by the animation if the animation does not have its own source value.
In: The target value that should be used by the animation if the animation does not have its own target value.
Out: The value of the animation at the given time. (The animation returns if the animation is or at .)

remarks.para: Note that the parameters need to be passed by reference. and are input parameters. The resulting animation value is stored in .

The values of the and the parameters depend on where the animation is used. If the animation is used to animate an , then the values depend on the position of the animation in the composition chain:
If the animation has replaced another animation using : is the last output value of the animation which was replaced and is the base value of the animated property.
If the animation is the first in an animation composition chain: and are the base value of the animated property.
If the animation is not the first in an animation composition chain: is the output of the previous stage in the composition chain and is the base value of the animated property.

If the animation is not used to animate an , the values need to be set by the user depending on the context where the animation is used. (In most cases it is safe to ignore the parameters and just pass default values.)

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.ITimeline
member.summary: Positions an animation along a timeline.

remarks.para: A is used to define when an animation starts and how long it is active. Timelines can be played back by the animation system.

Fill Behavior: The property defines the behavior of the animation when its duration is exceeded. The fill behavior indicates that the animation holds its last animation value when the end of the duration is reached. The last animation value is returned until the animation is reset or stopped. The fill behavior indicates that the animation should be removed when the end of the duration is reached.

Animation State: The current state of an animation (see enumeration ) depends on the current time on the timeline. The method can be used to query the current state for a given time value. The animation can be when the animation is scheduled but has not yet started. indicates that the animation is active. When the time reaches the end of the duration the state becomes either when the is set to or when the fill behavior is set to . When a timeline is it is automatically removed from the animation system.

Animation Time: The animation time is the local time of the animation. The animation time is required when the animation needs to be evaluated. The function can be used to convert a time value on the timeline to the animation time.
Nested Timelines: Timelines can be nested: A , for example, is a timeline that groups other animations. The time values of a nested timeline are relative to the parent timeline.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.KeyFrameAnimation`1
member.summary: Animates a value based on predefined key frames. (Base implementation.)
member.typeparam: The type of the animation value.

remarks.para: A key frame animation contains a list of key frames (see property ) that define the animation values at certain points in time. When the animation is played the class automatically looks up the animation value in the list of key frames.

Key Frame Interpolation: The property defines whether interpolation between key frames is enabled. When the property is set (default) the values between two key frames are interpolated. Each key frame animation class decides which type of a interpolation is most appropriate. For example, linear interpolation (LERP) is used for , , , etc. LERP is also used for (Spherical linear interpolation (SLERP) is not used for performance reasons). When interpolation is disabled, the animation returns the value of the previous key frame.

Please note that key frame animations (such as , , , etc.) provide only limited control over interpolation between key frames. Curve-based animations (such as , , , etc.) offer more advanced control: Curve-based animations allow to define an interpolation spline for each segment of the animation.

Cyclic Animations: A key frame animation, by default, runs until the last key frame is reached. The types and can be used to repeat the entire key frame animation (or a certain clip) for a number of times using a certain loop-behavior (see ).
Important: The key frame animation requires that the key frames are sorted ascending by their time value. The method can be called to sort all key frames.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Animation.LoopBehavior.Cycle
member.summary: The animation will be repeated if the time value goes past the end of the animation. (Note that the start and end value of cyclic animations needs to be identical to have smooth transitions between iterations.)

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Animation.LoopBehavior.CycleOffset
member.summary: The animation will be repeated if the time value goes past the end animation. Additionally, the animation values of the next cycle will be offset by the difference between the end value and start value of the animation to enable smooth transitions between iterations. (This behavior can be used to achieve cyclic animations that accumulate the animation values from one iteration to the next time.)

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Animation.LoopBehavior.Oscillate
member.summary: The animation will be automatically reversed and repeated. (This behavior is also known as 'auto-reverse' or 'ping-pong'.)

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.BlendGroup
member.summary: Blends two or more animations.

remarks.para: A blend group is a collection of animations (timelines). It automatically blends the animations based on a blend weight, which can be set using . The blend weight indicates the importance of the corresponding animation. For example, if one animation has a blend weight of 1 and another animation has a blend weight of 0.5 then the second has less influence on the animation result. A blend weight can be set to 0 to disable the animation.

The blend weights are internally normalized, meaning that the blend weights do not need be in the range [0, 1] when they are set. Blend weights can have any value equal to or greater than 0. The sum of all blend weights should be greater than 0 - i.e. at least one animation should to be active!
A blend group can contain s. In this case the animations within one are blended with the matching animations in the other s. The animations are matched by comparing the properties.

Synchronization: Most animations have different durations. When blending cyclic animations, for example, a "Walk" cycle and a "Run" cycle of a character, then it is important to synchronize the durations of the animations. When a "Walk" cycle and a "Run" cycle are blended with equal blend weights then the result should be the average of "Walk" and "Run". The duration of the blended animation should be the average both cycles. A key frame of the "Walk" cycle needs to be interpolated with the matching key frame of the "Run" cycle. In order to synchronize the animations the method needs to be called when all animations have been set.
Note that synchronization is optional. The methods does not need to be called if the contained animations do not need to be synchronized.

Limitations: A blend group has certain limitations.
The timelines within a blend group must be of type or implement .
If a is added to a blend group, it should only contain animations (). Nested timelines, such as within a , are not supported and will be ignored.
If a s is added to a blend group, the must be set for all animations in the . This is necessary because the blend group matches the animations of one with those of the other s by comparing the . A should not contain multiple animations that target the same property.
The of the animations within a blend group will be ignored. Only the property of the blend group itself will be read.
Animations must not be added to or removed from the blend group if the animation is already playing. (However, if all playing animation instances of the blend group are stopped and the associated s are recycled, then animations can be added or removed, and the blend group can be restarted.)
A blend group does not support additive animations. The property of contained animations will be ignored.
Animating Blend Weights: The blend weights in a blend group can be animated. The method returns an that represent the blend weight of the specified timeline and can be animated.

A blend group also implements the interface . The blend weights can also be retrieved using where the blend weights are identified using the strings "Weight0", Weight1", etc. The suffix is the index of the associated timeline.

member.summary: Gets or sets the time at which the animation begins.
member.value: The time at which the animation should begin. The default value is 0.

remarks.para: This property can be used to delay the start of an animation. The delay time marks the time on the timeline when the animation starts. The does not affect the delay. For example, an animation with a delay of 3 seconds, a duration of 10 seconds and a speed ratio of 2 will start after 3 seconds and run for 5 seconds with double speed.
Note: The delay time can also be negative. For example, an animation with a delay time of -2.5 seconds and a duration of 5 seconds will start right in the middle of the animation.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Animation.BlendGroup.Duration
member.summary: Gets or sets the duration for which the animation is played.
member.value: The duration for which the animation is played. The default value is .

remarks.para: The property can be set to override the duration of the animation. If is greater than the length of the animations in the blend group, the blend group will be repeated using the defined loop behavior (see ).

The effective duration depends on the : For example, an animation with a delay of 3 seconds, a duration of 10 seconds and a speed ratio of 2 will start after 3 seconds and run for 5 seconds with double speed.
The default value is , which indicates that the duration is 'automatic' or 'unknown'. In this case the blend group plays exactly once. A duration of can be set to repeat the animation forever.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Animation.BlendGroup.SynchronizeDurations
member.summary: Synchronizes the durations of the animations in the blend group.

remarks.para: Many animations that need to be blended have different durations. For example, a "Walk" animation has a different duration than a "Run" animation. In order to blend the matching frames the durations of the animations in the blend group need to be synchronized. Synchronization of durations is typically required for cyclic animations that should be mixed.

The method needs to be called once after all animations have been added to the blend group to synchronize them. (It does not need be called again if blend weights are changed or when animations are added or removed. However, if the duration of one animation is changed manually - for example, by appending key frames to a key frame animation - then needs to be called a second time to update the blend group.)

If the durations are synchronized the total animation duration of the blend group is the weighted average of all animations. If the durations are not synchronized then the total durations is determined by the longest animation in the blend group.

member.exception: The sum of the blend weights in the blend group is 0.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.Character.CcdIKSolver
member.summary: Modifies a skeleton using the cyclic-coordinate descent (CCD) algorithm.

remarks.para: This uses the cyclic-coordinate descent (CCD) algorithm to modify a bone chain to reach the position. determines the first bone in the chain. determines the last bone that is included in the chain. This IK solver rotates all bones in the chain, so that the tip of the bone chain reaches the position.
This solver uses an iterative algorithm. limits the maximal number allowed iterations. The algorithm ends early if the distance between the and the tip of the chain is less than .

Bone rotation limits:
Per default, the assumes that the bones can rotate in any direction without rotation limits. If the bone rotations should be limited (e.g. "do not rotate about the y axis" or "do not rotate more than 45"), then a callback must be set. The callback must be a method that checks the current bone rotations and removes any invalid rotations. See for more details.
See also for more general information.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Animation.Character.CcdIKSolver.TipBoneIndex
member.summary: Gets or sets the index of the tip bone.
member.value: The index of the tip bone.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Animation.Character.CcdIKSolver.TipOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the tip offset in tip bone space.
member.value: The tip offset in tip bone space. The default is a zero vector.
member.remarks: If this offset is zero, the IK solver will try to move the origin of the tip bone to the . For example, if the solver is used for an arm and the hand bone is the tip bone, then the character will "grab" the target with the wrist where the hand bone starts. The should be set to the offset from the wrist to the hand center. Then the target will be grabbed correctly with the hand center and not the wrist.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Animation.Character.CcdIKSolver.NumberOfIterations
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of iterations.
member.value: The number of iterations. The default is 10.

member.summary: Gets or sets the allowed distance error.
member.value: The allowed distance error. The default is 0.01.

remarks.para: This solver uses an iterative algorithm. The algorithm ends early if the distance between the and the tip of the chain is less than .

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.Character.IKSolver
member.summary: Modifies a using inverse kinematics (IK).

remarks.para: An inverse kinematics (IK) solver transforms the bones of a skeleton in order to achieve a desired pose. For instance, a rotates a bone (e.g. a head) to look into a desired direction. A can be used to bend/stretch a leg so that it touches the ground, or to make an arm reach a certain target.

An instances modifies a instance. And the goal is to point to or reach the position. The solver works in model space - not in world space. Therefore, and other positions and orientations must be specified in model space.

If is called and is (default), the is changed instantly. To avoid this instantaneous change, a limit can be set, then the bones will rotate slowly to the target pose over several calls. defines the maximal rotation velocity for each bone. (However, limiting is not ideal if the model is also animated, because the animation might reset the previous IK pose.)

The solver also has a parameter. If the weight is 0, the solver is disabled. If the weight is 1, the solver tries its best to make the skeleton reach the target. A weight less than 1 can be used to blend the target skeleton pose with the unmodified skeleton pose.

Note that the implements which means that it has properties which can be animated: The only property that can be animated is the , the other properties are not animatable. Animating the weight can be useful to fade an IK pose in or out.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.Character.JacobianTransposeIKSolver
member.summary: Modifies a skeleton using the Jacobian Transpose method.

remarks.para: This uses the Jacobian Transpose algorithm to modify a bone chain to reach the position. determines the first bone in the chain. determines the last bone that is included in the chain. This IK solver rotates all bones in the chain, so that the tip of the bone chain reaches the position.

This solver uses an iterative algorithm. limits the maximal number allowed iterations. The algorithm ends early if the distance between the and the tip of the chain is less than . In each iteration, the solver computes "forces" that pull the tip of the bone chain to the target. It then makes an Euler integration step to move the bones as determined by the computed forces. determines the time step of the numeric integration. If this value is too large, the solver becomes unstable. If this value too small, the solver needs many iterations to reach the target. A good value for a specific application must be determined by experimentation.

Bone rotation limits:
Per default, the assumes that the bones can rotate in any direction without rotation limits. If the bone rotations should be limited (e.g. "do not rotate about the y axis" or "do not rotate more than 45"), then a callback must be set. The callback must be a method that checks the current bone rotations and removes any invalid rotations. See for more details.
See also for more general information.

Caution:
This IK solver allocates heap memory and creates garbage. If garbage collector performance is important (e.g. on the Xbox 360 or Windows Phone 7), do not use this IK solver.

member.value: The tip offset in tip bone space. The default is a zero vector.
member.remarks: If this offset is zero, the IK solver will try to move the origin of the tip bone to the . For example, if the solver is used for an arm and the hand bone is the tip bone, then the character will "grab" the target with the wrist where the hand bone starts. The should be set to the offset from the wrist to the hand center. Then the target will be grabbed correctly with the hand center and not the wrist.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.Character.TwoJointIKSolver
member.summary: Modifies a two-bone chain to reach a certain target.

remarks.para: This modifies two bones in a bone chain. It is typically used for arms and legs. For the solver, the first bone (see ) can rotate freely. The second bone (see ) is attached with a hinge. The bone chain can contain more than 2 bones (e.g. the upper leg can consist of several bones). But only 2 bones are modified. The bones are rotated so that the end of the chain (defined by ) reaches the target.
Limitations of this IK solver: The bones must lie in a plane normal to the hinge axis; otherwise, the target will not be reached exactly.
See also for more general information.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.Character.SkeletonKeyFrameAnimation
member.summary: Animates a based on predefined key frames.

remarks.para: The is an optimized for character animation. A instance animates the bone transforms of a . It can animate a single bone (e.g. only the head), several bones (e.g. an upper body animation) or all bones of skeleton at once.

A is defined by adding key frames calling the method for the animated bones. The animation controls a bone if at least one key frame for the bone has been added (see also ). After adding all key frames, must be called. optimizes the animation data for fast access at runtime.

When key frames are added after calling , the animation is automatically reset into an editable state. All internal optimizations will be discarded! needs to be called again after all key frames are added.

Bone Channel Weights:
A weight can be set for each animated bone (see ). If the weight is 0, the bone is not animated. If the weight is 1, the bone is animated and replaces all preceding animations in the animation composition chain. If the weight is less than 1, the bone animation is blended with preceding animations.
Weights can be modified before and after . For example, weights can be modified while the animation is running.

Key Frame Interpolation:
A key frame animation contains a list of key frames that define the animation values at certain points in time. When the animation is played the class automatically looks up the animation value in the list of key frames. The property defines whether interpolation between key frames is enabled. When the property is set (default), the values between two key frames are interpolated using linear interpolation.

Cyclic Animations:
A skeleton key frame animation, by default, runs until the last key frame is reached. The types and can be used to repeat the entire key frame animation (or a certain clip) for a number of times using a certain loop-behavior (see ).
The first and the last key frame need to be identical to achieve a smooth cyclic interpolation.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Animation.Character.SkeletonKeyFrameAnimation.Compress(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Compresses the animation using a simple lossy compression algorithm.
member.returns: The amount of removed key frames in the range [0, 1]. 0 means that no key frames have been removed. 0.5 means that 50% of the key frames have been removed. Etc.

remarks.para: This method compresses the animation by removing key frames that can be computed by interpolation of nearby key frames. The threshold parameters define the allowed errors. If the thresholds are 0, this compression is lossless. If the thresholds are greater than 0 (recommended), the compression is lossy. The best way to determine optimal thresholds is to compare the compressed animation with the uncompressed animation visually.
This method does nothing if any threshold is negative.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.Character.ChainBoneMapper
member.summary: Maps the orientation of a whole bone chain.

remarks.para: A can be used if the mapped skeletons have a different number of bones. A bone chain starts at a bone ( and ). This bone defines the root (or origin) of the chain. And the chain has an end bone ( and ). The end bone is not included in the chain. It defines the tip of the chain.

The computes a direction vector from chain origin to chain tip for each chain. Then it will apply a bone rotation to the root bone, so that both chain direction vectors are parallel. - Only the bone rotation of the root bone of the target skeleton is modified. Other bones in the chain are not modified.
Note: The can also be used if the chain contains only a single bone.

For the target skeleton, the chooses a reference position which is either the bind pose or a direct-mapped pose (). determines which reference pose should be used. The chosen reference pose influences the twist of the whole bone chain.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.Character.DirectBoneMapper
member.summary: Copies a bone transform from one skeleton to the other skeleton.

remarks.para: This is the simplest . It simply reads the bone transform of the bone in the first skeleton and sets the same bone transform in the bone in the second skeleton. This mapping can be used if the mapped skeletons and bone orientations (in the bind pose) are very similar.

The works either in local bone space or in model space (see ). Per default, it works in local bone space ( is ). When working in local bone space, the bone mapper will transfer all orientation changes relative to the parent bones; for example, if the bone in the source skeleton was rotate up by 90, it will also be rotated up by 90 in the target skeleton. When working in model space ( is ) the bone mapper will transfer the absolute bone pose relative to the model space; for example, if the bone in the source skeleton is pointing down (relative to model space), the bone in the target skeleton will also be rotated so that it points down.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.Character.SkeletonMapper
member.summary: Controls the bone transforms of a to resemble the posture of another .

remarks.para:
Skeleton mapping is mainly used for two reasons:
Ragdoll Mapping: A high detail skeleton (e.g. 60 bones) is mapped to a low detail skeleton (e.g. 15 bones). The high detail skeleton controls a visual character model. The low detail skeleton creates a ragdoll.
Motion Retargeting: The animations of one character should be applied to another character that uses a different skeleton.

To use a skeleton mapper, set the two skeleton poses ( and ). If the skeletons use different model space (e.g. different forward or up directions), must be set. Then s must be added to the collection. A bone is only mapped if a for this bone is added to the skeleton mapper.
In most cases, the order of the bone mappers in the collection is relevant. It is recommended to map parent bones before their child bones.
After the bone mappers are defined, or can be called to map the bone transforms of one skeleton to the other skeleton.

member.summary: Handles efficient access to derived bone transformations.

remarks.para: This class computes transformations that are derived from the bind pose information and the current (animated) bone transforms: The bone pose transformations relative to parent bone space, the bone pose transformation relative to model space and the skinning matrices.

Dirty flags are managed for the bones. Whenever a bone transform of the is modified, must be called to set the dirty flag. When bone pose transformations are accessed, they are recomputed if necessary.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.Character.SkeletonPose
member.summary: Defines an animation pose of a .

remarks.para:
The class defines a skeleton in bind pose. The can be used to animate the bones of a skeleton. There are two ways to animate a skeleton using the animation system:
The skeleton pose implements the interface IAnimatableProperty<SkeletonPose>. This means that the skeleton pose can be treated as one animation value and can be animated as a whole. A skeleton pose can, for example, be animated using a .
The skeleton pose also implements the interface IAnimatableObject. The bones of the skeleton pose are animatable properties. This means that the bones can be animated individually. For example, a can be applied directly to a single bone.
You can find more details below.

Bone Transforms:
A bone transform is a local transformation that is applied to a bone. Bones are animated by changing the bone transforms (see and ). A bone transform is defined using a given in bone space. If a bone transform is the identity transformation (see ), then the bone is not animated and rendered in its bind pose.

Bone Poses:
A bone pose transformation matrix (bone pose) defines the resulting pose of bone after the bone transforms are applied. A bone pose describes the bone's position, orientation and scale relative to another coordinate space. A relative bone pose describes the pose of a bone relative to the parent bone (see ). An absolute bone pose describes the pose of a bone relative to model space ().

The bone poses are computed and updated automatically: Whenever a bone transform is changed, the relative bone pose, absolute bone pose and the skinning matrices of the affected bone needs to be updated. Additionally, the absolute bone poses and the skinning matrices of all bones attached to this bone need to be updated as well. The skeleton pose automatically keeps track of which poses and matrices need to be recomputed. The recomputation is performed automatically as soon as one of these values is required.
To update all derived transformations at once, can be called.

IAnimatableProperty Implementation:
The class implements the interface IAnimatableProperty<SkeletonPose> (see ). This means the itself is an animatable property. It can be animated using any animation of type IAnimation<SkeletonPose>. Typically a is used to animate the . This is the most efficient way to animate a skeleton.
Note: The as a does not have a base value and therefore cannot be used in some from-to-by animations and similar animations that require a base value.

IAnimatableObject Implementation (For Advanced Uses Only!):
The class additionally implements the interface . This means that the bones of the skeleton can also be animated independently. The animatable properties are the bone transforms given as IAnimatableProperty<SrtTransform>. The animatable properties can be accessed by calling the method passing the name of the desired bone as the parameter. (Bones need to be named if they should be animated independently.)
For example, a (or any other animation that implements IAnimation<SrtTransform>) can be applied directly to a bone.
Or, multiple s can be grouped together in a . The animations can be assigned to different bones by setting the animation's to the name of the bone. The can then be played as one animation.
Animating the this way is very flexible - but slower than animating it with a single .
Note: The s of the individual bones do not have a base value and therefore cannot be used in some from-to-by animations or similar animations that require a base value.

Tip:
When bone transforms are manipulated regularly, e.g. in an IK solver, numerical errors can accumulate. If this happens and the skeleton seems to "explode", try to normalize the rotation quaternions regularly.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Animation.Character.SkeletonPose.Update
member.summary: Updates all bone transformations.

remarks.para: This method recomputes all bone transformations (the relative/absolute bone poses and skinning matrices). It is generally not necessary to call this method explicitly because the transformations are recomputed automatically in and if they are invalid.

In certain cases in can be helpful to call explicitly: The method forces the skeleton pose to update the transformations immediately. This is helpful to perform all the computations at once and to avoid any stalls when calling or .

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.Character.SrtTransform
member.summary: Defines a transformation that scales, rotates and translates (SRT) an object.

remarks.para: This type represents an affine transformation consisting of a scaling followed by a rotation followed by a translation. Shearing (skewing) is not supported, thus this transformation cannot be used to describe general affine transformations. The is very similar to the type, but it adds a scale factor.

Non-uniform scalings require special attention: When multiplying two SRT matrices, the result can contain a shearing if a non-uniform scaling and a rotation is used. SRT transformations do not support shearing. It is recommended to use this type either only with uniform scalings, or with non-uniform scalings without rotations. It is allowed to set non-uniform scaling and a rotation, but multiplying this transform with other transforms may not give the expected results.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.IAnimationService
member.summary: Exposes the functionality of the animation system.

remarks.para: The animation service can be used to start/stop animations directly or create animation controllers, which can be used to interactively control animations.

Animatable Objects: Animations can be applied to objects that implement the interface or properties that implement . The class can be used to create a standalone property which can be animated. The can be used to wrap an existing property or field and make it "animatable".

Important: When animations are started or stopped the animations do not take effect immediately. That means the new animation values are not immediately applied to the properties that are being animated. The animations are evaluated when the animation system is updated (see ) and new animation values are written when is called.
The method (or one of its overloads) can be called to immediately evaluate and apply animations. But in most cases it is not necessary to call this method explicitly.

Weak References: The animated objects and properties are stored using weak references in the animation system. This means, animations can be started in a "fire-and-forget" manner. The caller does not have to worrying about "memory leaks". If a target object is garbage collected the animation system will automatically remove all associated animations and resources. This clean-up happens regularly when is called.

Note however, by registering a completion event handler for an animation (see ) a strong reference is created from the animation to the event handler. If the event handler accidentally keeps the animated object or properties alive then the animation is not removed automatically. Therefore, use the completion event handlers with caution. See for more details.

Thread-Safety: The animation service in general is not thread-safe. It is not allowed to simultaneously start multiple animations in different threads. Access to the animation service needs to be synchronized!

overloads.summary: Immediately evaluates the specified animations and applies the new animation values.

member.summary: Immediately evaluates the animations of the given objects and applies the new animation values.

remarks.para: When an animations are started or stopped, the values of the animated properties do not change immediately. The new animation values will be computed and set when the animation system is updated. See and .

But in certain cases when animations are started or stopped the animated properties should be updated immediately. In these case the method (or one of its overloads) needs to be called after the animations are started or stopped. This method immediately evaluates the animations and applies the new animation values to the specified objects or properties.
The method can also be called if animations are modified (e.g. key frames are added or removed) and the changes should take effect immediately.
In most cases it is not necessary to call this method because the animation system updates and applies animations automatically.
Note that does not advance the time of the animations. The animations are evaluated at their current time.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.Traits.IAnimationValueTraits`1
member.summary: Describes the properties of an animation value and defines operations that can be applied to animation values.
member.typeparam: The type of the animation value.

remarks.para: The describe the operations that can be performed on a certain type of animation value. This abstraction is necessary in order to treat different types of animations with the same code.

The interface and its implementing classes are used only internally in DigitalRune Animation. It is safe to ignore these types. (The following information is only relevant for users who plan to implement new types of animation values and want to reuse the existing animation classes.)

Reference Types vs. Value Types: Animation values can be reference types as well as value types, which makes the task a little complicated. Most method parameters need to be passed by reference to efficiently handle both cases.

Create, Recycle and Copy: The methods and can be used to create and recycle animation values. ( returns a previously recycled instance, if any is available. It is recommended to recycle and reuse animation values if they allocate memory on the managed heap.)
The method copies that data of one animation value to another.

Add, Identity, Invert and Multiply: In order to handle all types of animation with the same code we need to apply some math: The animation values form an algebraic group. The group has a group operation (see ) that represents the application of an animation value to a given value, an identity element (see ) and a function that computes the inverse of an animation value (see ). For efficiency, there is also a function that computes the repeated application of the same value. For example, if + represents the group operation then Multiply(x,3) = x + x + x.

Group Operation: The group operation depends on the type of animation value. Here are some examples: If the animation value is a real number the group operation is a simple addition. The group operation of a n-dimensional vector is a vector addition. If the animation value is a unit quaternion that represents a rotation, the group operation is a quaternion product (because two quaternions are combined using the quaternion product). Etc.
Note that, in general the group operations are not a commutative, meaning that the order of the operands is important! For example, the quaternion product is not commutative.

Identity Element: Every group has an identity element regarding the group operation. For example, the identity element of a scalar addition is 0. The identity of the vector addition is the zero vector. The identity of the quaternion product is the identity quaternion. Etc.

Inverse: Every value of the group has an inverse. For example, the inverse element of a real number r is -r. The inverse of an n-dimensional vector v is -v. The inverse of a unit quaternion q is q-1. Etc.

Interpolation: Another important part of animation is interpolation ("animation blending"). The interpolation of animation values is in most cases a weighted combination of the animation values. Animation values need to support two types of interpolation:
Interpolation of two values
Animations can be concatenated by adding them to animation composition chains. The output of one stage in the composition chain is blended with the output of the previous stage. The interpolation of two animation values is implemented by .
Interpolation of n values
Animations can be combined using a . The values of all animations in the blend group are blended together. A group can contain more than two animations. The blending of n animation values is implemented by , , and . (The blend operation is split into 3 operations which need to be called successively. needs to be called for each animation value.)
Optimizations: In order to improve performance - in particular on the Xbox 360 - most parameters are passed by reference. All operation happen in-place, i.e. no new objects are allocated.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationTransitions
member.summary: Provides a set of predefined transitions to start or stop animations.
member.remarks: Important: Animation transitions cannot be reused for multiple animations. When an animation is started a new animation transition needs to be created using one of the methods of this class.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Animation.AnimationTransitions.SnapshotAndReplace
member.summary: Takes a snapshot of the current animation and then starts the new animation. The new animation is initialized with the snapshot and takes effect immediately. The previous animations are stopped and removed from the animation system.
member.returns: The .
member.remarks: Usually, the property's base value is passed to the first animation in composition chain. When using a snapshot of the current animation value is created. The first animation in the composition chain will receive the snapshot instead of the base value as its input. The snapshot will be active until a new snapshot is created (by starting a new animation using ), or until all animations on the property are stopped.
